text: the australian capital canberra has gone
into a snap lockdown for the next seven
days after registering its first covert
case in more than a year close contacts
of that person have now been traced and
three more positive cases have been
confirmed while the territory chief
minister has described the current
situation as the most serious public
health risk to the area since the
pandemic began well we can cross over
live to canberra because henry bello is
a political journalist for the
australian network abc good to see you
you've only just moved back tell us what
some that what happened to you henry
oh well that's right i've just moved
moved back from london so when you
arrive in australia you have to do two
weeks of mandatory quarantine so i did
that
in a complex in the northern territory
just south of darwin and then left that
on sunday night and then moved back to
canberra had a few days of relative
freedom and now like most of the eastern
seaboard canberra where i am right now
has gone into lockdown joining melbourne
and sydney uh really where most of the
people live in australia so it's another
lockdown here another lockdown so what
are the conditions like then for you
henry
well the conditions that really have
just come into effect in the last couple
of hours are pretty strict by
international standards most shops are
closed so retail that's all closed uh
non-essential work uh is being told to
be done from home uh you can only go
outside to exercise for one hour if you
go outside you need to wear your mask at
all time that's a differentiation from
what we've seen in some parts of the
world where you need to wear a mask but
it's really interesting in canberra
because
this is the first case in this community
for 13 months over a year people have
been living without a single case of
covert in the community there's been
this sense that the the the people here
have avoided this by good luck and a
really vigilant uh stance against the
community transmission
so i wonder what the reaction is like
then given that this is one case as you
were saying it has then since been
traced three other positive cases have
been found but given how that compares
to say well places not least in the uk
the us how are people taking this
lockdown
it's been really interesting comparing
and having lived in the uk when there
was the first lock down to here which is
the first lockdown for people living
here and if you remember back a year ago
there was lots of reports of people
rushing to supermarkets and really you
know buying everything they could get
their hands on toilet paper essential
items like that we saw that this
afternoon the government announced that
there would be this lock down at about 2
p.m and then it was effective from 5 p.m
there was a rush on the supermarkets
by and large this is a town that's
mostly comprised of government workers
who work in the public servants
as a rule they tend to be very
law-abiding there is a sense that people
are willing to support this
hoping that it can just last for seven
days not what's happened in sydney which
is a seven week lockdown it really
doesn't have any end in sight
okay well henry really good of you to uh
take time out to speak to us and uh nice
to see you safely in australia having
left the uk
good luck with the lockdown henry bellow
abc correspondent thank you
